content.headline: First Trimester Exercise: Higher Activity Levels May Reduce Gestational Diabetes Risk
content.intro: New research reveals that exercise during the first trimester significantly reduces the risk of abnormal glucose screening and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). The study found that the amount of exercise needed to achieve these benefits may be higher than current recommendations.

sections.title: Key Research Findings
sections.content: A major study of 2,246 pregnant women found significant benefits from first-trimester exercise:
points: Women exercising ≥264 minutes weekly had 4.8% lower risk of abnormal glucose screening
High-exercise group had 2.1% lower risk of developing gestational diabetes
Benefits observed after adjusting for pre-pregnancy BMI and weight gain
Vigorous exercise was also beneficial and considered safe for most women
Exercise volume combines intensity, duration, and frequency

sections.title: Recommended Exercise Levels for Maximum Benefit
sections.content: The study suggests current recommendations might be insufficient for optimal diabetes prevention:
points: Current guidelines: ≥150 minutes of moderate exercise per week
Study recommendation: ≥264 minutes of moderate exercise per week
This represents about 38 minutes of daily exercise
Combination of cardiovascular and resistance exercises recommended
Always consult your healthcare provider before starting

sections.title: Safe First Trimester Exercises
sections.content: These activities are generally safe during early pregnancy:
points: Swimming and water aerobics - gentle on joints
Prenatal yoga - improves flexibility and relaxation
Light strength training - focus on proper form
